author: cbc
title: Calgary under snowfall warning as snow-route parking ban imposed
text:
Commuters, beware! Calgary could be hit by up to 10 more centimetres of snow Monday on top of the 16 centimetres that have blanketed the city over the weekend — prompting a snow-route parking ban, more weather alerts and havoc on the roads.
Environment Canada's snowfall warning for Calgary and most of southern Alberta remains in effect Monday. Calgary got 9.6 cm of snow on Sunday, and the city is expected to see another five to 10 cm of snow before it tapers off in the evening.
The high temperature is forecast to be just –19, feeling like –30 with the wind chill.
Parking ban starts at 6 p.m.
Trucks and graders are doing echelon plowing — staggering snowplows across all lanes of a road in one direction.— on priority 1 routes such as Crowchild Trail, the city's roads department director Troy McLeod said Monday.
"Roads are definitely in winter driving condition, so just take it easy out there," he said.
"Things will look a lot better this evening."
Calgary Transit tweeted that the Red Line LRT route is delayed by almost 20 minutes Monday morning because of the snow, and that some routes were being detoured, including routes 3, 20, 29, and 302.
The city announced a snow-route parking ban will start on Monday at 6 p.m. to allow crews to clear those streets, which are typically the main bus routes.
That means vehicles cannot be parked on streets marked with a snow route sign for 72 hours.
The snow-clogged roads have led to a spike in collisions. Between 4 p.m. Sunday and 3:45 a.m. Monday, there were 57 non-injury crashes and eight involving injury, police say.
On Sunday, there were 153 collisions between 4 a.m. and 4 p.m. Deerfoot Trail was snarled for much of Sunday as police dealt with multiple collisions.
Morning #CTRiders with bad weather condition we're trying to stay on time and get you safe to your destination. Dress warm today!
— @calgarytransit Highway travel outside Calgary is also treacherous.

Here, police deal with an accident that blocked traffic on Deerfoot Trail near Bow Bottom Trail on Sunday. (Terri Trembath/CBC)
Crowsnest Pass hit hard Highway 3 in the Crowsnest Pass is closed in both directions from Coleman to the B.C. border because of the weather. Commercial trucks are being parked at a roadside pullout in Frank.
Alberta Roads describes the conditions in the Crowsnest Pass area as hazardous — there's blowing snow and poor visibility. Travel is not advised. The municipality of Crowsnest Pass says on Twitter that it has opened a warming centre at the Elk's Hall in Blairmore for travellers who are stranded.
In B.C., traffic is being stopped at Sparwood until the highway reopens. But Alberta Roads said there is no estimated time for that to happen.
Environment Canada said on its website the Crowsnest area could get another 15 cm of snow on Monday with up to 35 cm at higher terrain. "Storm totals in some areas will exceed one metre," the agency said.
Snowfall warnings blanket southern Alberta The areas in the southern section of the province under a snowfall warning include:
Banff National Park. Brooks-Strathmore-Vulcan. Cardston-Fort Macleod-Magrath. Calgary. Crowsnest Pass-Pincher Creek-Waterton Lakes National Park. Cypress Hills Provincial Park-Foremost. Jasper National Park. Kananaskis-Canmore. Lethbridge-Taber-Milk River. Medicine Hat-Bow Island-Suffield. Okotoks-High River-Claresholm.
